thread.title: Here are five not-boring ways to spend Columbus Day weekend - Events
thread.title_full: Here are five not-boring ways to spend Columbus Day weekend - Events

author: boston.com
title: Here are five not-boring ways to spend Columbus Day weekend - Events
text:
The Columbus Day Parade in 2014. Photo by Pat Greenhouse / The Boston Globe It’s a long weekend, folks, and luckily, we have some ideas for events to keep on your radar. Here, an essential guide to some not-boring stuff happening over Columbus Day.
Honk! Fest
The 10th annual Honk! Festival for Activist Street Bands takes place all weekend long, beginning with a lantern parade on Friday night and culminating in a giant all-hands-in march from Davis Square to Harvard Square on Sunday. Come to participate or just to see the more than 25 professional bands who will perform. ( Various locations; Friday, October 9 at 3 p.m. to Sunday, October 11 at 6 p.m.; free to attend; all ages )
A photo posted by HONK! Festival (@honkfestival) on Sep 30, 2014 at 11:02am PDT
Harvard Square Oktoberfest
The Honk! Parade will end right in Harvard Square, where the 37th annual Oktoberfest will take place. ‘Not another fall-centric festival!’ you’re probably thinking. Yes, it is—this time with over 200,000 people, tons of food from all over the world, plus all the usual cool things festivals have: crafts, sidewalk sales, vintage things, gifts, and...did we mention all the food? Prost! ( Sunday, October 11 from 12 p.m.-6 p.m.; Harvard Square, free to attend )
Illuminus
Illuminus, a nighttime light and sound art installation, comes to Lansdowne Street as a part of HUBweek . The locally grown, multi-sensory spectacle attracted over 10,000 last year when it took place at the SoWa Arts District. ( Saturday, October 10 from 6:30 p.m.- 2:30 a.m.; Lansdowne St.; free to attend; all ages )
A photo posted by Will Wolff Herbert (@jerseyneue) on Oct 29, 2014 at 12:57pm PDT
Boston Zine Fest
Looking to get your voice heard, or at least to find some cool new reading material? Join more than 80 independent zine publishers for a weekend full of workshops and panels celebrating zine and DIY culture in Boston. ( Make Shift Boston and Simmons College; Saturday, October 10 at 12 p.m. through Sunday, October 11 at 6 p.m.; free to attend; all ages )
Boston Columbus Day Parade
The Columbus Day Parade is happening the Sunday before the holiday and has been a tradition in the North End and East Boston since 1937. This year, it’ll kick off in Boston and wind through Hanover Street, Atlantic Ave., and Endicott. Plus, this way, you can actually use your extra day off to, you know, sleep in. (But if sleeping isn’t your thing— what kind of demon are you? —then know that the Fenway Alliance is opening its doors on Monday to the New England Conservatory, MFA, Gardner, and more for free.) ( Parade kicks off Sunday, October 11 at 1 p.m.; North End neighborhood; free to attend )
More fall festivites around New England:
 Oktoberfest in Harvard Square features six stages of live music, plus the legendary HONK! Parade. International food vendors, as well as those selling art, jewelry, and clothing flock to the square for the day. Cambridge, Oct. 11, noon-6 p.m. Dina Rudick / The Boston Globe The Cambridge 5k Okotoberfest is a German-themed road race followed by a post-race party. Cambridge, Oct. 4, 9:30 a.m. Photo courtesy Cambridge 5k Oktoberfest 2015 Harpoon Octoberfest is a 26-year-old tradition that includes fall Harpoon beers, bratwursts, and a German chocolate cake-eating contest. Boston, Oct. 2, 5:30- 11 p.m. and Oct. 3, 1-7 p.m. The Boston Globe Archives Douglas Octoberfest is the town’s biggest event of the year. With food, games, crafts, rides, and live music, Main Street is transformed for the day-long celebration each year. Douglas, Massachusetts, October 3. Jessica Guimond / Photo courtesy Douglas Oktoberfest Facebook In Old Heidelberg’s beer garden, they serve a full Oktoberfest menu in September. The celebration also includes live music and family-friendly entertainment. Bethel, Connecticut, Sept. 18-20 and 25-27, and Oct. 2-4. Photo courtesy Old Heidelberg Oktoberfest Oktoberfest Maine is celebrating its third year with a German band, relays, as well as both keg-throwing and beer-themed contests. Topsham, Maine, Sept. 19, noon-7 p.m. Photo courtesy Oktoberfest Maine Oktoberfest Vermont will hold its inaugural event this year on Burlington’s Waterfront Park. The weekend features a fly fishing competition, food and crafts from local vendors, live music, and, of course, beer from local breweries. Burlington, Vermont, Sept. 24-27, start and end times vary by day. Image courtesy Oktoberfest Vermont Milford Oktoberfest features German food, dancers, an oompah band, as well as seasonal brews. Bridgeport, Connecticut, Sept. 26, noon-9 p.m. Photo courtesy Milford Oktoberfest Stowe Oktoberfest opens with a parade of marching bands, floats, and classic cars. The weekend features live music, food, and local Vermont beers. Stowe, Vermont, Oct. 2-4, start and end times vary by date. Michael Taylor / Stowe Rotary Oktoberfest Facebook Page NB Oktoberfest will feature nearly 50 brews, including 35 regional beers. There will also be live music, with Chadwich Stokes (of Dispatch fame) headlining. New Bedford, Massachusetts. Oct. 3, 3 p.m. - midnight Photo courtesy South Coast Business Alliance Harpoon Octoberfest at the Vermont brewery is a tradition of oompah music, bratwurst, chicken, dancing, cake eating, and barrels of Harpoon beer. Windsor, Vermont, Oct. 10 and 11, noon - 6 p.m. Christopher Lehault / Flickr Swine & Stein Oktoberfest is a day-long street party complete with Maine craft beer, local musicians, and local pork products. Gardiner, Maine, Oct. 10, 11:30 a.m. - 6:30 p.m. Photo courtesy CoyoteGTP / Flickr Bennington Oktoberfest is an annual celebration in Colgate Park featuring German food, music, art, and beer. Bennington, Vermont, Oct. 10, 11 a.m. - 5 p.m. Photo courtesy Bennington Oktoberfest by Norshaft Lions Club Acadia Oktoberfest is a two-day celebration with classic drinking games like flip cup and beer pong as well as costume and keg-tossing contests. Southwest Harbor, Maine, Oct. 10 and 11, noon-5 p.m. Photo courtesy Acadia Oktoberfest Sugarbush Resort’s Oktoberfest features games, Bavarian-style food and drink, and performances from the Mad Bavarian Brass Band. Warren, Vermont, Oct. 11, 11 a.m.- 5 p.m. John Atkinson / Coutesy Sugarbush Resort Wachusett Mountain ski resort hosts Applefest, complete with an Oktoberfest celebration. They serve German cuisine and open up a beer garden, while also offering scenic skyrides on the ski lift. Princeton, Massachusetts, Oct. 17-18, 10 a.m. - 5 p.m. Photo courtesy Wachusett Applefest International Oktoberfest is a weekend full of live music, local and international beers, live music, and folk dancing. Providence, Rhode Island, Oct. 17-18, noon.
